instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
Hi, I have a liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is stuck at 5v with 0a

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>:12.21v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>: 5.16v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL>:0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0.949v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>: 3.269v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL>: 0v

Any help would be really appreciated

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C7910</CAPACITOR> Pin 1 -  <SIGNAL>LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> = 1.463v
<CAPACITOR>C7905</CAPACITOR> Pin 1 - LDO0 - <SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 0.00v
<CAPACITOR>C7906</CAPACITOR> Pin 1 - LDO1 - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.00v
<CAPACITOR>C7914</CAPACITOR> Pin 1 - LDO2 - <SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 0.00v
<CAPACITOR>C7911</CAPACITOR> Pin 1 - LDO3 - <SIGNAL>PMU_LD</SIGNAL>)<SIGNAL>3_OUT</SIGNAL> = 1.80v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
Check <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR>.
Also check diode mode to ground on the coils around <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message: Maybe some crap under <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> on the left side or under T2 chip?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
Sorry, I was looking at wrong schematic (01598).

You may have bad <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, or accumulated crap underneath.
Try heating with quality flux.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message: Fluxed, heated and gave it a few little taps but no change unfortunately

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
With <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> removed I'm still getting those low readings on diode mode. Could it be anything else before I order a <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>?

I expected it to alter the diode mode reading when removed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
The diode mode readings on the coils are not caused by <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, but T2.
You should compare the values with good board.
